ygData.subject: Re: Pole Balancing, physics maths and friction
ygData.msgSnippet: Regarding the pole balancing maths, there does appear to be a mistake in much of the literature. The origin of the pole balancing maths is this book from 1967:

From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Regarding the pole balancing maths, there does appear to be a mistake
in much of the literature. The origin of the pole balancing maths is
this book from 1967:

   Dynamics of Physical Systems, Robert H. Cannon Jr.
   https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/0486428656

page 703 onwards.

The derivation includes a term J for rotational inertia (i.e. to
describe how the mass is distributed along the pole), for which they
use J = (ml^2)/3, which is the formula for a rod with evenly
distributed mass (as opposed to e.g. a point mass half way up the
pole, or at the end of the pole).

   See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_moments_of_inertia

For the single pole task the standard length is 1 metre so J just
becomes m/3. That reduced form seems to be everywhere in the
literature, i.e. the fact that the J term is dependent on pole length
has been lost, which is fine if the length is one, but when the double
pole task was devised the second pole has length 0.1m, but it's still
using the rotational intertia term for a 1m pole.

At this point I think I'm going to fix the maths is sharpneat and give
the tasks different names to distinguish between the canonical tasks
and the new improved ones. I might try and publish a definitive pole
balancing derivation just for kicks too, given that I'm 90% of the way
there!

Colin
